text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
DAWN
- Pakistan's trade deficit during July amounted to $24.6 million, down $25.3 million compared to the corresponding month of last year.
- The consumer price index rose 11.59 percent in July compared to the year-ago month.
- Pakistan has offered a soft short-term credit of $10 million to Syria to facilitate building two ships at Karachi Shipyard.

- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has hinted at the possibility of seeking the army's help to get hold of saboteurs and terrorists in case law and order is not restored through the present available means especially in Punjab province.
- The private carrier Bhoja Air has been given permission to operate cargo flights on any route between Pakistan, Britain and the United States.
BUSINESS RECORDER
- The government plans to import 10,000 tractors from former socialist countries.
- The government has accepted an offer from Deutsche Bank AG for a $25 million three-year financing facility at LIBOR plus 0.69 percent.
- The project of an off-shore gas import pipeline from Qatar, which could also carry Iranian gas to both Pakistan and India, has been jepordised by local political events and regional disputes.
FINANCIAL POST
- The National Bank of Pakistan is considering closing 100 branches to minimise its deficit.
- Commerce Minister Ishaq Dar said the U.S. Overseas Private Insurance Corporation should revive its cover for U.S. investors to encourage them to invest in Pakistan.
THE NEWS
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said a national plan is being prepared to curb terrorism, sectarianism, drug-trafficking, gun-running, smuggling and other heinous crimes.
- Heavy monsoon rains in Islamabad on Tuesday took nine lives, including a woman and four children.
- The opposition Pakistan People's Party is likely to boycott the sessions of the National Assembly and Senate.
THE NATION

- The Accountability Cell at the Prime Minister's Secretariat has prepared a reference against Asif Ali Zardari, the jailed husband of former prime minister Benazir Bhutto, for allegedly causing loss of 673 million rupees to the exchequer in the privatisation of Ittehad Chemicals.
